title: 115_hr3119
content: The "21st Century STEM for Girls and Underrepresented Minorities Act" is introduced to provide grants for preparing girls and underrepresented minorities in the field of STEM education. This Act amends Title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to focus on preparing these groups for the 21st century. The Secretary can provide grants to local educational agencies to establish programs for girls and underrepresented minorities in STEM fields. Eligibility requires submitting an application with specified information. The application for STEM program grants must include a program description, collaboration between schools, recruitment process, and planned activities for improving education in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology for girls and underrepresented minorities in grades K-12. The STEM program grants prioritize applicants who collaborate with institutions experienced in increasing girls' and minorities' participation in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology. Funds are used to prepare these groups for careers in STEM fields. The STEM program aims to promote careers in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology among girls and underrepresented minorities by educating parents, providing tutoring and mentoring programs, and establishing partnerships with role models in the field. The STEM program aims to promote careers in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology among girls and underrepresented minorities through various initiatives such as attending events, after-school activities, and summer programs designed to develop interest and skills in these fields. The STEM program includes software, equipment, field trips, academic advice, and assistance to encourage girls and underrepresented minorities in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology. The STEM program aims to support underrepresented minorities and female students in taking advanced courses in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics by providing financial assistance for internships and offering professional development for teachers to address gender and racial biases in the classroom. The STEM program aims to support underrepresented minorities and female students in pursuing advanced classes and careers in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology fields. The Secretary requires local educational agencies to use the assistance provided to supplement, not supplant, other funds for these activities. Agencies must provide evaluations to the Secretary at the end of each school year. The local educational agency must provide a description of programs, data on curriculum and partnerships, time spent on grant subjects, and any other required information to the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations for this part includes $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2018 and necessary sums for the following 4 years.
